questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

 

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic compound: Phenolic compounds are effective disinfectants but are generally less effective against a broad spectrum of bloodborne pathogens compared to chlorine compounds.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Quaternary ammonium compounds are good for general disinfection but are not recommended for blood spills as they are less effective against non-enveloped viruses and spores.

 

Option D. Alcoholic compounds: Alcohol-based disinfectants are effective for surface disinfection but are not ideal for blood spills as they can coagulate proteins, making blood more difficult to clean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.

 

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

 

If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

 

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

 

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

 

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paragonimiasis: Incorrect, as the Sabin-Feldman dye test is not used for diagnosing Paragonimiasis.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Incorrect, the diagnosis of hydatid disease is primarily performed using imaging techniques and the Casoni skin test.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus: Incorrect, Cryptococcus infections are typically diagnosed using fungal cultures and cryptococcal antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Additional Information

 

Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:

 

  1. Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  2. Montenegro test – Kala azar
  3. Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  4. Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  5. Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

questions.text: A patient was injured with a rusted metal object. What is the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin in such cases?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

 

Tetanus toxin, also known as tetanospasmin, is produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. When a person is injured by rusted metal, this bacterium can enter the body and produce the toxin. Tetanospasmin specifically targets the nervous system by binding to receptors on motor nerve terminals and getting internalized. It then travels retrogradely to the central nervous system where it inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons.

 

GABA and glycine normally function to inhibit motor neurons and prevent excessive muscle contraction. By blocking these neurotransmitters, tetanospasmin causes unopposed muscle contractions, leading to the characteristic muscle spasms and rigidity seen in tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibit the release of Acetylcholine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit acetylcholine (Ach) release. Instead, botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum inhibits the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis rather than muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Inhibit the release of epinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not affect the release of epinephrine. Epinephrine release is primarily regulated by the adrenal glands and not significantly impacted by tetanospasmin.

 

Option D. Inhibit the release of norepinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit the release of norepinephrine. Norepinephrine release is also regulated by different mechanisms and is not directly influenced by tetanospasmin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin) inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contractions and the characteristic spasms of tetanus.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fever and he is diagnosed with condition caused by a lactose fermenting bacteria, he is advised for culture, Which culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mac conkey agar

 

Culture media is used to differentiate lactose and non-lactose fermenter - MacConkey agar

 

It is used to distinguish lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

it is a selective and differential culture medium

 

Contents of MacConkey agar: Peptone, Lactose, Agar, Sodium Taurocholate

 

 

Lactose fermenters seen as pink colonies, non-lactose fermenters seen as colorless or pale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bile salt agar: Incorrect. Bile salt agar is primarily used for the isolation of enteric pathogens, particularly Salmonella and Shigella, but it does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters

 

Option C. LJ media: Incorrect. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) media is used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It does not differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Option D. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar: Incorrect. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar is used for the cultivation of fungi, including yeasts and molds. It is not used to differentiate lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to distinguish lactose fermenters, which appear as pink colonies, from non-lactose fermenters, which appear as colorless or pale colonies.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: A Cattle farmer with a scab lesion in the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. Most likely organism which is responsible for his condition is? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacillus anthracis

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. Bacillus anthracis is a brick/box car shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the centre. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule.

 

It can cause -

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax
  • Pulmonary anthrax
  • Intestinal anthrax

 

 

Box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of bacillus anthracis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria monocytogens: Incorrect. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive rod that can cause listeriosis, but it does not have the brick/boxcar shape and is not typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option C. Bacillus cereus: Incorrect. Bacillus cereus can cause food poisoning and is a gram-positive rod, but it does not typically present with the brick/boxcar shape or cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus species are gram-positive cocci and do not exhibit the described morphology or cause anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacillus anthracis, with its brick/boxcar shape and central spores, is the causative agent of cutaneous anthrax, a zoonotic infection often seen in individuals handling livestock or animal products.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

 

Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

 

The Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV), belongs to the family of DNA viruses Herpeseviridae. It causes Kaposi sarcoma (a vascular malignancy) and B cell lymphoproliferative diseases such as primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD).

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

 

Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a selective decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to a significant reduction in red blood cells (RBCs), while white blood cells (WBCs) and platelets remain unaffected. This condition differs from aplastic anemia, where all three cell lines (RBCs, WBCs, and platelets) are decreased.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This condition typically presents with low Hb but is associated with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs due to insufficient iron for hemoglobin synthesis. It does not specifically cause a decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

 

Option B. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia results from defective DNA synthesis, often due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, leading to the presence of megaloblasts (abnormally large erythroid precursors) in the bone marrow, rather than a reduction in their number.

 

Option C. Pernicious anemia: A form of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency due to intrinsic factor deficiency. Similar to megaloblastic anemia, it is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis with megaloblastic changes in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a specific decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia with normal WBC and platelet counts.

choices.text: Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide
Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool
It is an obligate intracellular organism

questions.text: A patient who underwent a renal transplant 3 months ago comes with complaints of diarrhea for the last 9 days. The stool sample was subject to Kinyoun stain revealing 4-6m structures shown below. Which of the following is true about the organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in stool

 

Oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool.

 

Causative organism - Cryptosporidium hominis (more common), C.parvum

 

Causes intractable diarrhoea in immunocompromised patients.

 

Infective form - oocyst.

 

The oocyst is spherical or oval and measures about 5 μm in diameter. Oocyst does not stain with iodine and is acid-fast. The wall of the oocysts is thick, but in 20% cases, wall may be thin. These thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection.

 

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of the oocysts in feces.

 

  • A direct wet mount reveals colorless, spherical oocyst of 4-5 μm, containing large and small granules.
  • The oocysts are difficult to visualize in unstained wet preparations. Modified ZN staining is the method of choice and by this method oocysts appear as red acid-fast spheres, against a blue background.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathogen does not show autoinfection: This is incorrect. Cryptosporidium can indeed cause autoinfection. Thin-walled oocysts are responsible for autoinfection, perpetuating the infection within the host.

 

Option B. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common organism implicated worldwide: While Cryptosporidium parvum is a common cause, Cryptosporidium hominis is more frequently implicated in human infections worldwide.

 

Option D. It is an obligate intracellular organism: Cryptosporidium is not strictly obligate intracellular; it can survive outside the host as an oocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective after being excreted in the stool, and the infection can cause severe diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are identifiable by their acid-fast property in modified Ziehl-Neelsen stains.

 

Comparative features of coccidian parasites:

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

 

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves T cells, particularly cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) and helper T cells (TH1 cells). When these T cells recognize antigen presented by antigen-presenting cells (like macrophages and dendritic cells), they secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells. This leads to an inflammatory response that can cause tissue damage. The process typically takes 24-72 hours to develop, hence the term "delayed."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Macrophages play a crucial role in presenting antigens and secreting cytokines, but they are not the primary cells involved in mediating the type IV hypersensitivity response.

 

Option C. Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells are important antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells, but they are not the main effector cells in type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions, where they mediate tissue damage through the release of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in response to immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presented with case of diarrhea after eating sea food/ oyster, showing Kanagawa phenomenon. What is the causative organism? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus causes Food-borne gastroenteritis

 

  • MC presentation
  • Following uncooked sea food (e.g. Oyster and shellfish) intake.
  • Watery diarrhea (MC), dysentery, abdominal cramps.
  • Extraintestinal manifestations → wound infection, otitis and sepsis.

 

 

Bipolar staining – safety pin appearance is seen in 5 bacteria’s –

 

Mnemonic

 

 

Note - Kanagawa phenomenon

 

  • V. parahaemolyticus  produce Beta  hemolysis on special blood agar medium → called the Wagatsuma agar
  • Wagatsuma agar  → High-salt (7%) blood agar (defibrinated human or rabbit blood) medium containing d-mannitol as the carbohydrate source.
  • Hemolysis observed on Wagatsuma agar medium, referred to as the Kanagawa phenomenon (KP).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio cholera: Causes cholera, characterized by severe watery diarrhea but not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option C. E. coli: Can cause gastroenteritis but is not associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Option D. Vibrio vulnificus: Can cause severe infections from seafood consumption but is not typically associated with the Kanagawa phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahemolyticus is the causative organism of gastroenteritis following the consumption of uncooked seafood, identified by the Kanagawa phenomenon. The most common symptoms are watery diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal cramps.

 

Additional Information -

 

Classification based on Salt Requirement

 

1. Nonhalophilic vibrios:

  • Can grow without salt but 1% salt is optimum for their growth.
  • Cannot grow at higher salt concentrations.
  • Examples → V. cholerae and V. mimicus

 

2. Halophilic vibrios: 

  • Cannot grow in the absence of salt.
  • Can tolerate and grow at higher salt concentration of up to 7–10%.  Examples  → V.   parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus and V. vulnificus.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe pneumonia following influenza infection. Culture shows gram-positive cocci growing as alpha-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, optochin sensitive. Identify the organism: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Explanation: 

 

The characteristics described are typical of Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus): gram-positive cocci in chains, alpha-hemolytic colonies on blood agar, and optochin sensitivity. This organism commonly causes secondary bacterial pneumonia following viral respiratory infections, particularly influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae: Gram-negative coccobacillus requiring X and V factors, grows on chocolate agar, not blood agar.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, produces beta-hemolysis, and is coagulase-positive. Not sensitive to optochin.

 

Option D. Moraxella catarrhalis: Gram-negative diplococci, oxidase-positive, grows on blood agar but doesn't show hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand key diagnostic features of respiratory pathogens:

  • S. pneumoniae: Alpha-hemolysis, optochin sensitivity
  • Colony morphology and biochemical tests essential for identification
  • Post-viral bacterial pneumonia often caused by specific pathogens

Importance of distinguishing between different respiratory bacteria

questions.text: Weil’s disease is caused by:   (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira Interrogans

 

Explanation: 

 

Weil’s disease refers to a severe form of leptospirosis caused by Leptospira interrogans. Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. It presents with various clinical findings including fever, jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage, and refractory shock. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals, especially rodents.

 

Leptospirosis Overview:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Borrelia Recurrentis: Causes relapsing fever.

 

Option C. Treponema Endemicum: Causes bejel.

 

Option D. Borrelia Burgdorferi: Causes Lyme disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Weil’s disease, a severe form of leptospirosis, is caused by Leptospira interrogans and involves symptoms such as jaundice, renal failure, and hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: Which component of the HIV genome is necessary for the virus to enter the host cell membrane? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GP120

 

GP120 is a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope that binds to the CD4 receptors on host cells. This binding is crucial for the initial attachment of the virus to the host cell, facilitating the subsequent steps that lead to viral entry. GP120 interacts specifically with the CD4 receptor, which is predominantly found on the surface of T-helper cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CCR5: CCR5 is a co-receptor on the host cell surface that HIV uses in conjunction with the CD4 receptor to enter the cell. However, it is not a component of the HIV genome but rather a part of the host cell.

 

Option C. GP41: GP41 is another glycoprotein found on the HIV envelope that assists in the fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane after GP120 has bound to the CD4 receptor. It facilitates the entry of the viral core into the host cell cytoplasm.

 

Option D. CXCR4: CXCR4 is another co-receptor used by HIV to enter host cells, particularly in later stages of infection. Like CCR5, it is a part of the host cell and not a component of the viral genome.

 

Educational Objective:


GP120, a glycoprotein on the HIV envelope, is necessary for binding to CD4 receptors on host cells, facilitating viral entry.

questions.text: A patient presents with productive cough for 3 months, evening rise of temperature, and significant weight loss. A sputum examination is ordered for AFB. What are the constituents of the primary stain used in this test? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basic fuchsin and phenol (Carbol fuchsin)

 

Explanation: 

 

The classical Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining for acid-fast bacilli uses carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, which is composed of basic fuchsin and phenol. The phenol enhances the penetration of the dye into the mycolic acid-rich cell wall of mycobacteria, while basic fuchsin provides the red color that resists decolorization with acid-alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toluidine blue and malachite green: These are components of Albert's stain used for identifying metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Option C. Crystal violet and safranin: These are components of Gram staining, with crystal violet as primary stain and safranin as counterstain.

 

Option D. Methylene blue and iodine: These are components used in different staining techniques but not together as primary stain for AFB.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the composition and principles of different bacterial staining methods:

  • ZN stain: Carbol fuchsin (primary), acid-alcohol (decolorizer), methylene blue (counterstain)
  • Purpose: To identify acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Principle: Mycolic acid in cell wall retains primary stain despite acid-alcohol treatment

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and a characteristic skin lesion as shown in the image, 5 days after a camping trip in the Rocky Mountains. The rash started on his ankles and wrists, later spreading to his trunk. Which is the most likely diagnosis? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows a characteristic maculopapular rash of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted by Dermacentor ticks.

 

Key features of RMSF include:

  • Rash appears 2-4 days after fever onset
  • Begins as small, flat, pink macules on wrists, forearms, and ankles
  • Centripetal spread (periphery to trunk)
  • May involve palms and soles
  • Associated with severe headache and fever
  • Treatment: Doxycycline

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrub typhus: Incorrect. Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, characterized by an eschar (black, necrotic ulcer with surrounding erythema) at the site of chigger bite, not a diffuse rash.

 

Option C. COVID-19: Incorrect. Various cutaneous manifestations may occur but typically presents with respiratory symptoms. The rash pattern is not characteristic of COVID-19.

 

Option D. Lyme disease: Incorrect. Presents with erythema migrans - a bull's eye lesion that appears at the tick bite site, different from the diffuse rash of RMSF.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To differentiate between tick-borne illnesses based on characteristic rash patterns - RMSF shows a centripetal spreading maculopapular rash, while scrub typhus shows an eschar, and Lyme disease shows erythema migrans.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (Twisted PYQ)

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - immunocompetent adults
  2. Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome - younger adults
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - children
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

Pure red cell aplasia due to parvovirus B19 occurs primarily in immunocompromised patients or those with chronic hemolytic anemia, not typically in immunocompetent adults.

 

2. Papular-purpuric gloves and socks syndrome: Correct. Younger adults this is a correct pair as this syndrome is commonly observed in younger adults with parvovirus B19 infection.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Correct. Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy, particularly in the second trimester, can lead to severe fetal complications including hydrops fetalis.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - children: Correct. Also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, this is a classic manifestation in children presenting with characteristic facial rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand that parvovirus B19 manifestations vary by host factors:

  • Pure red cell aplasia occurs in immunocompromised hosts
  • PPGSS affects young adults
  • Hydrops fetalis is a risk in pregnancy
  • Erythema infectiosum is common in children

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

 

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PC assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have been approved for diagnostic purposes of Clostridium difficile infection due to high sensitivity, specificity and rapid turnaround time.

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

 

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin- producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or ELISA, or pseudo membranes seen in the colon.

 

Other diagnostic methods include:

 

  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure strain isolation from culture: Stool culture on selective media can identify C. difficile. However, it is not the best method due to longer turnaround times and the need for specialized techniques. It is highly sensitive but less practical for rapid diagnosis. Also the mere presence of clostridium difficile does not suggest infection with the organism unless toxin production is checked.

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence:

Immunofluorescence can be used for detecting C. difficile antigens. It is less commonly used due to the complexity of the procedure and lower sensitivity compared to PCR.

 

Option D. Toxin Detection by ELISA: ELISA can detect toxins in stool samples. Although it is a useful method, it is less sensitive and specific compared to PCR, making it a secondary choice for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

 

List of Oncogenic Microbe:

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and myalgia 10 days after a camping trip. Peripheral blood smear examination reveals characteristic inclusion bodies (morulae) in neutrophils as shown in the image. Identify the most likely causative organism? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Explanation:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes Human Granulocytic Anaplasmosis (HGA). The key diagnostic feature is the presence of morulae (mulberry-like inclusion bodies) in neutrophils, as opposed to monocytes.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: Through Ixodes scapularis (deer tick)
  • Symptoms: Fever, headache, myalgia, malaise, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms occurring 1-2 weeks after tick exposure
  • Diagnosis: Visualization of morulae in neutrophils on blood smear, PCR, and serologic testing
  • Treatment: Doxycycline is the drug of choice

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Incorrect. While it also causes similar symptoms, E. chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils.

 

Option C. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever and does not form morulae in any white blood cells.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Causes Mediterranean Spotted Fever and also does not form characteristic morulae.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To differentiate between Anaplasma and Ehrlichia based on their characteristic cell tropism - Anaplasma forms morulae in granulocytes (neutrophils) while Ehrlichia forms them in monocytes. Both are tick-borne illnesses treated with doxycycline.

 

GAME - Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10–40%.

 

CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north – the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. Outbreak in Gujarat, India occurred in 2011.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever is mostly endemic to the south and central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Option C. Ebola virus is located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa

 

Option D. Hendra virus mainly confined to north-eastern coast of Australia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

choices.text: To hold and support the specimen slide
To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen
To adjust the focus and clarity of the image

questions.text: What is the primary function of the condenser in a compound microscope? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

 

The condenser in a compound microscope is a crucial component located within or below the stage (sub-stage). Its primary function is to gather and concentrate light from the microscope's illuminator and direct it into a light cone that focuses on the specimen.

 

Condenser Function:

 

  • Light Regulation: The condenser focuses and concentrates the light onto the specimen to ensure optimal illumination, which is critical for viewing the specimen clearly.
  • Improving Image Quality: By regulating and directing the light precisely, the condenser enhances the contrast and clarity of the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To magnify the specimen image: Magnification is achieved by the objective lenses and eyepiece, not by the condenser.

 

Option B. To hold and support the specimen slide: The stage is the part of the microscope that holds and supports the specimen slide, not the condenser.

 

Option D. To adjust the focus and clarity of the image: Focus adjustment is achieved using the coarse and fine adjustment knobs, not the condenser.

 

Parts of Microscope

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesia

 

Babesia is not an intracellular parasite of hepatocytes. It is an intra-erythrocytic parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma gondii can infect hepatocytes as part of its lifecycle.

 

Option B. Plasmodium: The liver stage (hepatic schizogony) of Plasmodium involves hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Leishmania species infect macrophages, which can reside in the liver, leading to intracellular infection in hepatocytes indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obligate intracellular parasites-

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Microsporidia

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

 

The condition shown in the image is characterized by painful vesicles, which is a hallmark of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV causes fluid-filled vesicles that are often painful, and these lesions can occur on the skin or mucous membranes, including genital areas. The vesicles eventually rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers. HSV can present as recurrent outbreaks, especially during periods of stress or weakened immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis typically presents with white, curd-like discharge and redness, particularly in mucous membranes like the mouth or vagina. It does not cause vesicles or painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless chancre in the primary stage, followed by a rash and other systemic symptoms in later stages. Vesicles are not a feature of syphilis.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers but does not form fluid-filled vesicles. The ulcers are more ragged and deeper compared to those seen in HSV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: Patient came with fever, rash and eschar formation. On examination, mite bite was also present. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support this diagnosis are:

 

  1. The presence of eschar, which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax.
  2. The mite bite, which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).
  3. The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites, commonly known as chiggers.

 

Triad – Eschar; Regional lymphadenopathy and Maculopapular rash

 

 

 

 

*Coxiella and  Bartonella  are now excluded from this family

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax: Anthrax is caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis and is not transmitted by mite bites. It is a zoonotic disease acquired through contact with infected animals or their products, inhalation of spores, or ingestion of contaminated food.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: This is another rickettsial disease, but it is transmitted by ticks, not mites. The presence of a mite bite in the given scenario rules out this option.

 

Option D. Epidemic Typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, epidemic typhus presents with a rash but does not typically include eschar formation, nor is it associated with mite bites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The presence of eschar, fever, rash, and a mite bite are key clinical features suggestive of this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

 

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

 

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22m, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42m diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HBeAg: Incorrect, as HBeAg is a Hepatitis B envelope antigen associated with the virus's replication and infectivity but not known as the Australia antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg: Incorrect, HBcAg or Hepatitis B core antigen is associated with the core of the virus but is not referred to as the Australia antigen.

 

Option D. HBV-DNA: Incorrect, this refers to the genetic material of the Hepatitis B virus itself and is not synonymous with the Australia antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis

 

The image provided shows a GMS stain of BAL (Bronchoalveolar lavage) fluid, which is a common diagnostic method used to identify pathogens in patients with pneumonia. The patient is HIV-positive with a low CD4 count, indicating immunocompromise. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in such patients, often referred to as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The hallmark appearance of Pneumocystis in a GMS stain is the black, crushed ping-pong ball-like cysts against a green background, which is visible in the image.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus: Cryptococcus usually appears as encapsulated yeast cells, often seen in India ink preparations or mucicarmine stains. It does not show the crushed ping-pong ball appearance seen in the image.

 

Option B. Mucor: Mucor species are identified by their broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typically visible on H&E or PAS stains, not GMS. The morphology seen in the image does not match Mucor.

 

Option D. Candida: Candida typically appears as budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which do not resemble the crushed ping-pong ball appearance shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and is identified by its characteristic crushed ping-pong ball appearance in GMS-stained samples.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens

 

When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following markers will always be present in his serum, even during recurrences, or if he develops chronic hepatitis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti Hbc Ab

 

The Anti-HBc antibody (C) is the marker that will always be present in a patient's serum if they have been exposed to Hepatitis B virus (HBV). This marker is indicative of both past and ongoing infection and remains detectable for life. It indicates a previous or ongoing infection with HBV and is present in both acute and chronic stages of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBc Ag: Hepatitis B core antigen is typically not detectable in the serum. It is found within the hepatocyte and not usually present in the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Anti HBs Ab: The antibody against the Hepatitis B surface antigen indicates immunity to HBV, either from past infection or vaccination. It is not present during chronic infection without recovery.

 

Option D. HBe Ag: Hepatitis B e antigen is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is not present in all stages of infection, especially in chronic carriers where the virus may not be actively replicating.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following image depicts: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Production of monoclonal antibodies

 

The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

 

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

 

 

The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.

 

Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell lines for viral culture: This option is incorrect as the process depicted is not related to culturing cells for viral growth, but rather for antibody production.

 

Option C. Vaccine synthesis: This option is incorrect because vaccine synthesis generally involves the creation of attenuated or inactivated pathogens or their components, not the production of monoclonal antibodies.

 

Option D. Process of genetic engineering: This option is incorrect as genetic engineering involves manipulating an organism's genes directly, whereas the process depicted is about producing antibodies through hybridoma technology.

 

Educational Objective:


The process depicted in the images is the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

 

Albert stain is used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria, such as those seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The staining technique involves two solutions: Albert stain 1 and Albert stain 2. Albert stain 1 contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, which are basic dyes with a high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. Toluidine blue stains the granules blue, while Malachite green provides a green background. This differential staining helps in visualizing the metachromatic granules distinctly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect as Carbol fuschin is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria, and methylene blue is a counterstain in that procedure.

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is incorrect because Carbol fuschin is not used in Albert staining; it is used in acid-fast staining procedures.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect for Albert staining. Methylene blue is a basic dye used in various other staining techniques, but not in Albert stain.

 

Educational Objective:


Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: Diarrhea, falling leaf motility, 4 pairs of flagella, tennis racket shape are seen in? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

Explanation:

 

Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes gastrointestinal illness, typically presenting with diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and malabsorption. The characteristic "falling leaf" motility and the presence of four pairs of flagella (eight flagella in total) are key diagnostic features.

 

Giardia lamblia exists in two forms:

 

  1. Trophozoite: The active, motile form. It has a distinctive shape often described as a tennis racket, teardrop, or monkey face. The trophozoite has two nuclei, four pairs of flagella, and two parabasal bodies.
  2. Cyst: The infective form. It is oval-shaped with a thick wall, containing four nuclei when mature. The cyst form is responsible for transmission through contaminated water or food.

 

The images provided show the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia with its characteristic features, including the flagella and the distinctive shape.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Listeria: Listeria is a bacterium, not a protozoan. It does not exhibit the described features of falling leaf motility or multiple flagella.

 

Option C. Trichomonas: Trichomonas is a flagellated protozoan but does not have the same morphological characteristics as Giardia lamblia. It typically affects the urogenital tract rather than causing diarrhea.

 

Option D. Balantidium coli: This is a ciliated protozoan that causes dysentery, not typically associated with the described motility or flagella characteristics of Giardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia is identified by its unique "falling leaf" motility, presence of four pairs of flagella, and its characteristic tennis racket or teardrop shape in its trophozoite form. It is a common cause of diarrhea and gastrointestinal discomfort.

 

Additional Information:

 

Classification:

 

 

Life cycle

 

 

Malabsorption  syndrome

 

  1. Abdominal pain , Nausea and vomiting
  2. Malabsorption of fat (steatorrhea)  → leads to foul smelling profuse frothy diarrhea
  3. Malabsorption of Disaccharidase (lactose, xylose) → leading to lactose intolerance
  4. Malabsorption of vitamin A, B12 and iron
  5. Protein loosing enteropathy.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:
