Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus multilocularis

 

E. multilocularis leads to alveolar or multilocular hydatid cyst. The liver is the most commonly affected organ. The multilocular infiltrating lesion appears like a grossly invasive growth, without any fluid or free brood capsule or scolices which can be mistaken for a malignant tumor.

 

Patients present with upper quadrant and epigastric pain. Liver enlargement and obstructive jaundice may also be present. It may also metastasize to the spleen, lungs and brain in 2% cases.

 

The prognosis is very grave and if untreated, 70% cases progress to death.

 

Surgical resection, when possible, is the best method of treatment. Albendazole therapy is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery. In those cases, where surgery is not possible, indefinite treatment with albendazole is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Echinococcus granulosus: Causes cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease, which typically involves the formation of fluid-filled cysts rather than alveolar-like lesions.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebic liver abscesses, which are different in appearance and pathology from the lesions caused by Echinococcus multilocularis.

 

Option D. Cysticercus cellulose: The larval stage of Taenia solium, which causes cysticercosis. It can form cysts in various tissues but does not cause alveolar-like lesions in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, leading to a serious condition known as alveolar echinococcosis. The prognosis is poor without treatment, emphasizing the importance of early detection and appropriate therapy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: Identify the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The above image shows giardia lamblia.
  • Cysts are resistant forms and are responsible for transmission of giardiasis. Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces (diagnostic stages). The cysts are hardy and can survive several months in cold water.
  • Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water, food, or by the fecal-oral route (hands or fomites).
  • In the small intestine, excystation releases trophozoites (each cyst produces two trophozoites).
  • Trophozoites multiply by longitudinal binary fission, remaining in the lumen of the proximal small bowel where they can be free or attached to the mucosa by a ventral sucking disk.
  • The cysts are infectious when passed in the stool or shortly afterward, person-to-person transmission is possible.
  • Giardia lamblia exists in:
    • Infective form - Quadrinucleate cyst
    • Tennis racket shaped trophozoite is actively motile with central axostyle with pair of nuclei
    • Oval shaped cyst denoted with cyst wall

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba dispar: Morphologically similar to E. histolytica but is non-pathogenic and does not cause invasive disease.

 

Option C. Balantidium coli: The only ciliate known to infect humans, characterized by large size and the presence of cilia.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebiasis, with cysts and trophozoites distinguishable by their size and internal structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia in its cyst form, is the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated water, food, or fecal-oral route.

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid-water

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue

 

Clinical history along with microscopic picture is suggestive of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Microphotograph is of TB bacillus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis on an oil-immersion smear slide stained with Ziehl-Neelsen or acid-fast staining of a clinical sample. Bacilli are long and rod-shaped; a bacillus is indicated by a black arrow. Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is a differential staining technique that was initially developed by Ziehl and modified later by Neelsen, hence the name Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

 

Reagent used in Ziehl Neelson stain are-

 

  • Carbol-Fuschin (Primary dye)
  • 20% sulphuric acid or acid-alcohol (Decolorizer)
  • Methylene Blue dye (counterstain) or malachite green

 

The use of acid-alcohol in the technique earned it the name Acid-Fast Stain and the application of heat in the technique gives it the name the hot method of Acid-Fast staining

 

Mycobacterium, Nocardia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, and some fungi contain a thick cell wall made up of lipoidal complexes known as mycolic acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentian violet - iodine - alcohol - safranin: This sequence is used for Gram staining, not for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option B. Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid - water: This sequence is not used for any standard bacterial staining protocol.

 

Option C. Methanol - methylene blue - acid - water: This sequence does not correspond to the Ziehl-Neelsen stain or any other standard staining protocol for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, involving carbol fuschin, acid-alcohol, and methylene blue, is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis in clinical samples. This technique highlights acid-fast bacilli, which retain the red color of carbol fuschin even after decolorization with acid-alcohol.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

 

Explanation:

 

  1.  The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  2. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  3. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  4. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  5. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.

 

The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.

 

Established agents:

 

  • C. perfringens
  • C. novyi
  • C. septicum

 

Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kennel worker

 

The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Parasite eggs are passed in the feces of infected animals (cats, dogs) into the soil, where the larvae hatch out. Hence kennel workers are at high risk.

 

This condition also known as creeping eruption (ground itch) is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

On coming in contact with human skin, the larvae penetrate the skin to cause infection.

 

In normal animal host, the larvae are able to penetrate the deeper layers of the skin by reaching there via circulation.

 

Once they enter intestine, they mature sexually and lay more eggs that are then excreted to repeat the cycle.

 

However, in a human host, which is an accidental host for the parasite, the larvae are unable to penetrate the basement membrane to invade the dermis, so that the disease remains confined to the outer layers of the skin.

 

The larvae produce itching papules, which develop into serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis. With the movements of the larva in the skin, the lesion also shifts, hence the name "creeping eruption''. Scratching may lead to secondary bacterial infection.

 

Transient creeping eruptions may be produced sometimes by the human hookworm, Necator americanus. Gnathostomiasis and sparganosis may produce larva migrans, where the lesions are deeper, subcutaneous or in the muscles. Loeffler's syndrome may occur in one-fourth to one-half of the cases.

 

A rapidly moving lesion is produced by Strongyloides stercoralis particularly in immune persons. This is known as larva currens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lifeguard in a swimming pool: This occupation does not typically involve exposure to soil contaminated with animal feces.

 

Option C. Veterinarian: While veterinarians do work with animals, they are less likely to be exposed to soil contaminated with the specific nematodes causing cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Poultry Worker: This occupation involves working with birds, which are not typically hosts for the nematodes causing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous larva migrans, caused by nematode larvae from Ancylostoma species, is commonly associated with occupations that involve close contact with contaminated soil and animal feces, such as kennel workers.

 

Additional Information

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique is '2'.

 

 

The sandwich ELISA is a type of Enzyme-linked immunosorbent Assay that uses two antibodies: a capture antibody and a detection antibody. It is called a sandwich because your antigen is bound between antibodies. The purpose of any ELISA is to detect the presence of a target antigen in a sample. In a sandwich ELISA the target antigen is bound between a capture antibody and a detection antibody. The capture antibody is immobilized on a surface, while the detection antibody (conjugated to an enzyme or fluorophore label) is applied as a last step before quantitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the substrate that produces a detectable signal when reacted with the enzyme.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the primary detection antibody that binds to the antigen.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the capture antibody that is immobilized on the surface and captures the antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. tuberculosis

 

  • Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell wall.
  • It is released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis.
  • Urine LAM testing is especially useful in diagnosing TB in patients with HIV and low CD 4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, and its diagnosis is typically made through skin biopsy and slit-skin smear. Urine LAM is not used for diagnosing leprosy.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma species cause respiratory and urogenital infections. They lack a cell wall and, therefore, LAM is not relevant to their diagnosis.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterial pathogen causing listeriosis, diagnosed typically through blood culture or cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Urine LAM is not applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.
